great singleplayer game.

I shouldn't really have to tell you if this is good or not. Like seriously, it's made by valve, of course it's gonna be amazing. Anyway story is absolutely exceptional, the voice actors did an incredible job, and I was surprised to see JK Simmons make an appearance. In terms of gameplay, it's portal. It has the classic puzzling fun of the original game, plus a few extra gameplay concepts that are used well throughout the game, and make it feel just as fresh as it felt playing the original game for the first time. Exceptional, 10/10.

[h1]Awesome[/h1]
The game is fun, and the story is very clever. It was worth the entire $1.6 I paid for it. I recommend this game for anyone who has the money.
Spoiler part:
[spoiler]The ending is one of the best I've ever seen. I was actually just messing around because I thought that the ending was based on time, and I just shot the moon with my Portal Gun. That was [b]so[/b] clever. The final song "Want You Gone" also gave a wholesome to the two games.[/spoiler]

The best, most entertaining puzzle game with loveable sarcastic characters and a unique storyline. dont forget to play co-op as well!

The other night I was bored and just wanted to get a decent Co-op game to play with my friend.
I heard that this game was a good time, but was still a little skeptical, due to it coming out so long ago.
In all the Co-op mode was some of the most fun I've ever had in a gaming experience. 
I don't even like to play sing player games, but I wanted to give it a try and it was great. 
All jokes hit and the gameplay was somewhat challenging

Ingredients
1 Tbsp vegetable oil 
4 cloves garlic 
1-inch fresh ginger 
1 medium (1 lb.) sweet potato 
1 medium onion 
1 tsp cumin 
Â¼ tsp crushed red pepper 
1 (6oz.) can tomato paste 
Â½ cup natural style chunky peanut butter 
6 cups vegetable broth 
Â½ bunch (2-3 cups chopped) collard greens 
Â¼ bunch cilantro, garnish (optional) 
Method
Peel and grate the ginger using a small holed cheese grater. Mince the garlic. SautÃ© the ginger and garlic in vegetable oil over medium heat for 1-2 minutes, or until the garlic becomes soft and fragrant.
Dice the onion, add it to the pot, and continue to sautÃ©. Dice the sweet potato (Â½ inch cubes), add it to the pot, and continue to sautÃ© a few minutes more, or until the onion is soft and the sweet potato takes on a darker, slightly translucent appearance. Season with cumin and red pepper flakes.
Add the tomato paste and peanut butter, and stir until everything is evenly mixed. Add the vegetable broth and stir to dissolve the thick tomato paste-peanut butter mixture. Place a lid on the pot and turn the heat up to high. 
While the soup is coming up to a boil, prepare the collard greens. Rinse the greens well, then use a sharp knife to remove each stem (cut along the side of each stem). Stack the leaves, then cut them into thin strips. Add the collard strips to the soup pot.
Once the soup reaches a boil, turn the heat down to low and allow it to simmer without a lid for about 15 minutes, or until the sweet potatoes are very soft. Once soft, smash about half of the sweet potatoes with the back of a wooden spoon to help thicken the soup. Taste the soup and add salt if needed (will depend on the brand of broth used). 
Serve the stew hot with a few cilantro leaves if desired. 
Note:  Add mushrooms, peas, beans and any other vegetables you can think of. For extra nutrients, add a few tablespoons of nutritional yeast and ground flax. You can also double the batch and freeze a few litres. You can serve it over rice or pasta or quinoa or have it alone. Enjoy!
